case_vignette: A 6-MONTH-OLD MALE PRESENTS TO DERMATOLOGY CLINIC WITH A RED SPOT ON THE LEFT FOREARM THAT WAS NOTICED A FEW WEEKS AFTER BIRTH. THE PARENTS NOTE THAT IT HAS BECOME LARGER OVER THE PAST FEW WEEKS AND DENY ANY SPONTANEOUS BLEEDING. THE INFANT DOES NOT SEEM TO BE BOTHERED BY THE LESION. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION REVEALS A BRIGHT RED OVOID THIN PLAQUE WITH TELANGIECTASIAS ON DERMOSCOPY.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a bright red spot on my left forearm that has been growing larger over the past few weeks.
Has the spot been itchy, painful, or does it bleed?
No, the spot is not bothering me and it does not bleed.
Do you have a history of similar skin issues, or any significant medical conditions?
No, I do not have a history of similar skin issues or any significant medical conditions.
Have you had any recent sun exposure or burns on the area where the spot has appeared?
No, there hasn't been any recent sun exposure or burns on the area where the spot appeared.
Has anyone in your family had skin cancer or any other significant dermatological conditions?
No, nobody in my family has had skin cancer or any significant dermatological conditions.
Has the spot changed in color or developed any irregular borders?
The spot has not changed in color or developed any irregular borders; it is a bright red ovoid thin plaque.
Final Diagnosis: Granuloma annulare
